talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one electorate or ESA may elect to be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the electorate of Fowler may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the electorates of Blaxland, Hughes, Prospect, Reid or Werriwa. The Fairfield/Liverpool ESA is most closely aligned with the electorate of Fowler and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to this ESA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 March 2005:

item.para: What formal assessment has the Government made of the potential risk to Australia posed by an outbreak of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) virus in South East Asia.
What formal assessment has the Government made of the capability of regional governments to respond to an outbreak of the virus (a) poultry and (b) humans.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Department of Health and Ageing assesses the potential risk to Australia of a human HPAI outbreak in the following manner:

On a daily basis the Department undertakes a systematic review of data sources, media and information from regional and global authorities such as the World Health Organization (WHO). The assessment is carried out by expert medical officers and scientists within the Department and communicated to relevant government agencies three times a week.

Through regular meetings of external expert groups and, when required, frequent teleconferences. These expert groups are the National Influenza Pandemic Action Committee (NIPAC) chaired by the Chief Medical Officer, Professor John Horvath and the Communicable Disease Network of Australia (CDNA).
On a regular basis though an Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) of central agencies. The IDC reviews the data and assess impact on respective areas of responsibility and initiates necessary action.

With respect to the potential risk to Australia of an animal HPAI outbreak, there have been ongoing assessments of potential risks posed by the outbreak in South East Asia. These assessments have taken place through dialogue and formal meetings with industry and government stakeholders that include the Australian Government Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing, AusAID, the Australian Animal Health Laboratory and other Commonwealth and state and territory agencies.

(2) (a) and (b) The capability of regional governments to respond to outbreaks of avian influenza and other zoonotic and communicable diseases is factored into the design and implementation of regional interventions aimed primarily at enhancing surveillance, diagnostic capacity and emergency preparedness. The Department of Health and Ageing and the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry have been integrally involved with AusAID in a project to assess the capability of current countries affected by avian influenza to detect and to respond both to poultry and human outbreaks of avian influenza. The assessment has also involved organisations such as the WHO, Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), World Organisation for Animal Health, ASEAN, as well as regional governments.

In countries where HPAI outbreaks have occurred, the Australian Government is working closely with regional governments to identify immediate assistance needs and longer term capacity building priorities. It is also working closely with the ASEAN Secretariat to identify regional, trans-border approaches to monitoring, surveillance and preparedness for avian influenza and other zoonotic and communicable diseases.

Specifically with respect to animal health outbreak capability, the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has a high level of knowledge about disease control capacity in a number of countries in the region and it is clear that a number of countries have found dealing with the HPAI outbreak very difficult. The difficulties include social, technical, economic, environmental and political factors.

The governments of Indonesia, East Timor and Papua New Guinea presented country reports at the Quadripartite Quarantine Consultations in Canberra in February 2005. The reports included information on highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreaks, surveillance and diagnostic capacity and status of response preparedness.

Further assessments undertaken by the Department of Health and Ageing in the area of human disease outbreak capability in the region include our participation in the formal evaluation of human disease surveillance systems in the Pacific and in Indonesia. Further assessment of Asian -Pacific capacity has been formalised through meetings and workshops organised by the Western Pacific Regional Office (WPRO) of WHO. Australia has been involved in these forums and the capacity assessments are available to Australia through the WPRO office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 March 2005:

item.para: What enquiries has Government made about the status of any contingency plans prepared by the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor to respond to an outbreak of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

Can he say what the key agencies are in the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor that would be responsible for the management of an outbreak of HPAI in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

What enquiries has the Government made about plans of the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor to destroy poultry infected with the HPAI virus in the event of an outbreak.

What enquiries has the Government made about the capacity of the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor to diagnose an outbreak of the HPAI virus in the event of an outbreak in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

What enquiries has the Government made about the surveillance systems the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor has in place to detect an outbreak of the HPAI virus in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

What efforts has the Government made to identify areas for potential development assistance to the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor to manage an outbreak of the HPAI virus in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

What development assistance has the Government provided to the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Papua New Guinea, and (c) East Timor through the aid budget to prepare for a potential outbreak of the HPAI virus in (i) poultry and (ii) humans.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s questions is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: , (b) and (c) (i) The Australian Government Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF) has informal knowledge of the capacity of each of these countries to respond to outbreaks of HPAI in animals. Indeed, for Indonesia (the only one of these three countries currently known to be infected) and East Timor, DAFF has been involved in direct assistance measures to improve the surveillance and reporting activities for this poultry disease.

(1) (a), (b) and (c) (ii) The Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing has informal knowledge of the capacity of each of these countries to respond to outbreaks of HPAI in humans and works closely with the regional offices of the World Health Organization (WHO) which have more detailed information on the contingency plans of member states.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

The Australian Government has provided assistance for the Indonesian Government’s contingency plans through a $3 million, 3 year initiative funded under Australia’s bilateral aid program. In March 2004, emergency assistance for contingency planning was delivered through a partnership with the WHO Office in Jakarta. Activities included epidemiological investigations, a public media campaign and the supply of anti-viral medicines. More recently, efforts have focused on long-term strengthening of Indonesia’s communicable disease outbreak surveillance and response capabilities. This expanded support is being delivered through WHO.
Papua New Guinea

While there are no known incidents of avian influenza in Papua New Guinea (PNG), the PNG National Department of Health has broadly discussed contingency planning at Departmental Meetings since outbreaks occurred in the region in 2004. AusAID project personnel have provided support for such discussions during various technical working group meetings over the ensuing period.
PNG’s National Disaster Management Office does not currently have a contingency plan in place.
East Timor

While there have been no known incidents of avian influenza in East Timor, the Government of East Timor has advised that it does have contingency plans in the event of an identified outbreak of HPAI in poultry and humans. Specifically, the Ministry of Health would cooperate with the Quarantine Unit of the Ministry of Agriculture in the event of an identified outbreak. Within Dili Hospital, arrangements are in place to offer initial assistance to victims in the event of positive identification of an outbreak of avian flu.

(2) (a), (b) and (c) (i) and (ii) In general, in each country, the Ministry of Agriculture or equivalent is the key agency responsible for HPAI outbreaks in animals, and the Ministry of Health or equivalent is the key agency responsible for HPAI outbreaks in humans.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

The lead responsibility broadly rests with the Directorate General of Livestock Services under the Ministry of Agriculture in the case of poultry infections, and with the Ministry of Health in the case of human infection. A key aspect of aid program assistance is support for a joint taskforce between the Indonesian Ministries of Health and Agriculture, to effectively manage any avian influenza outbreaks.
Papua New Guinea

The key government agencies are the Curative Health Services and Disease Control Branch of the National Department of Health, PNG Laboratory Association, Centre for Public Health, the National Agricultural Quarantine and Inspection Authority (NAQIA) and the National Disaster Management Office.
East Timor
The key government agencies are the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Division of Quarantine) and the Ministry of Health (Division of Communicable Disease).

(3) (a), (b) and (c) Risk management strategies in Australia take into account a variety of possible responses to HPAI infection that may be adopted and as such, specific enquiries have not been made of these countries. However, as Indonesia is currently infected, it has been noted that animal health authorities have used both vaccination and limited poultry destruction approaches to control HPAI infection.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

Australian Government officials attend monthly avian influenza donor coordination meetings in Jakarta, as convened by the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO). At these meetings, the Indonesian Government has reiterated its strategy of vaccinating and selectively depopulating poultry in high risk locations.
Papua New Guinea

The NAQIA does not currently have a response plan in place however it is developing a proposal for assistance from the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research to develop a response plan for the four high risk livestock disease threats, which includes HPAI.
East Timor

While there are no known reports of avian influenza outbreaks in East Timor, a Ministerial Decree is in place outlining procedures for handling any such outbreaks should they occur in either poultry or humans. The government of East Timor works closely with the WHO in the development of such monitoring, surveillance and response mechanisms.

(4) (a), (b) and (c) (i) and (ii) Informal enquiries concerning diagnostic capacity for HPAI in a number of regional countries have been made and, where appropriate, training and other relevant assistance measures have been offered and subsequently accepted to varying degrees. The FAO and other international agencies have been active in building capacity for regional countries to control HPAI in poultry. The DAFF assists relevant agencies in East Timor and PNG to send samples to the regional avian influenza reference laboratory which is the CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory.

The high-level diagnostic capacity required to identify the currently circulating HPAI virus strain and other novel influenza strains is limited worldwide. The Australian Government has this capacity through its WHO Collaborating Centre for Influenza based in Melbourne, one of only two in the region, and through the CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory based in Geelong. These key reference laboratories provide vital diagnostic support for other countries in the region.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

Assistance with the Indonesian Government’s contingency plans for a possible outbreak of avian influenza in humans is being provided through a $3 million, 3 year initiative funded under Australia’s bilateral aid program. In March 2004, emergency assistance for such planning was delivered through a partnership with the WHO Office in Jakarta. Activities included epidemiological investigations, a public media campaign and the supply of anti viral medicines. More recently, efforts have focused on long term strengthening of Indonesia’s communicable disease outbreak surveillance and response capabilities, including in relation to diagnosis. This expanded support is being delivered through WHO.
Papua New Guinea

AusAID has worked with the PNG National Department of Health to discuss epidemics management, including surveillance and diagnosis of communicable diseases. The PNG National Department of Health works directly with the WHO in this area.
East Timor

The Ministry of Health, with assistance from the WHO, has capacity to diagnose HPAI virus infection in humans. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, through cooperative arrangements with the North Australian Quarantine Strategy based in Darwin has capacity to diagnose an outbreak of HPAI virus in poultry.

(5) (a), (b) and (c) (i) Informal enquiries concerning animal health surveillance systems for HPAI in a number of regional countries have been made and, where appropriate, training in the conduct of surveillance activities, including the design of HPAI specific surveys, has been offered and subsequently accepted to varying degrees. The FAO and other international agencies have been active in building capacity for regional countries to control HPAI in poultry. The DAFF conducts joint animal health surveys with relevant agencies in PNG and East Timor, and funds an animal health monitoring program in PNG.

(5) (a), (b) and (c) (ii) The Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing has informal knowledge of the human health surveillance systems of each of these countries to detect outbreaks of HPAI in humans and works closely with the regional offices of the WHO, who have more detailed information on the surveillance systems of member states.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

In March 2004, the Australian Government, through the bilateral aid program contributed $325,000 for initial assistance focussing on epidemiological investigation, public information and awareness raising and supply of anti-viral medications. In June 2004, AusAID signed an MOU with the Indonesia WHO Office on a program to expand that assistance and strengthen surveillance and diagnosis and emergency response for communicable diseases in Indonesia ($3 million over 3 years).
Papua New Guinea

While there are no known cases of avian influenza in PNG, the NAQIA does have a surveillance program carrying out quarterly testing in PNG’s border region with Indonesia. In addition, any poultry or blood samples that are sent for laboratory testing are routinely screened for HPAI.
East Timor

The Ministry of Health, with assistance from the WHO, has capacity to monitor and provide capacity development in surveillance of communicable diseases including HPAI virus in humans. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Division of Quarantine) is implementing a government directive to ban the import of poultry and poultry products. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries surveillance systems to detect an outbreak of the HPAI virus in poultry is based at all points of entry to the country e.g Dili airport and border entry points at Suai, Batucade (Bobonaro) and Oecussi.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries surveillance systems to detect an outbreak of the HPAI virus in poultry is based at all points of entry to the country e.g Dili airport and border entry points at Suai, Batucade (Bobonaro) and Oecussi.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: , (b) and (c) (i) Informal enquiries concerning animal health surveillance systems for HPAI in a number of regional countries have been made and, where appropriate, training in the conduct of surveillance activities, including the design of HPAI specific surveys, has been offered and subsequently accepted to varying degrees. The FAO and other international agencies have been active in building capacity for regional countries to control HPAI in poultry. The DAFF conducts joint animal health surveys with relevant agencies in PNG and East Timor, and funds an animal health monitoring program in PNG.

(5) (a), (b) and (c) (ii) The Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing has informal knowledge of the human health surveillance systems of each of these countries to detect outbreaks of HPAI in humans and works closely with the regional offices of the WHO, who have more detailed information on the surveillance systems of member states.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

In March 2004, the Australian Government, through the bilateral aid program contributed $325,000 for initial assistance focussing on epidemiological investigation, public information and awareness raising and supply of anti-viral medications. In June 2004, AusAID signed an MOU with the Indonesia WHO Office on a program to expand that assistance and strengthen surveillance and diagnosis and emergency response for communicable diseases in Indonesia ($3 million over 3 years).
Papua New Guinea

While there are no known cases of avian influenza in PNG, the NAQIA does have a surveillance program carrying out quarterly testing in PNG’s border region with Indonesia. In addition, any poultry or blood samples that are sent for laboratory testing are routinely screened for HPAI.
East Timor

The Ministry of Health, with assistance from the WHO, has capacity to monitor and provide capacity development in surveillance of communicable diseases including HPAI virus in humans. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Division of Quarantine) is implementing a government directive to ban the import of poultry and poultry products. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries surveillance systems to detect an outbreak of the HPAI virus in poultry is based at all points of entry to the country e.g Dili airport and border entry points at Suai, Batucade (Bobonaro) and Oecussi.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: , (b) and (c) (ii) The Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing has informal knowledge of the human health surveillance systems of each of these countries to detect outbreaks of HPAI in humans and works closely with the regional offices of the WHO, who have more detailed information on the surveillance systems of member states.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

In March 2004, the Australian Government, through the bilateral aid program contributed $325,000 for initial assistance focussing on epidemiological investigation, public information and awareness raising and supply of anti-viral medications. In June 2004, AusAID signed an MOU with the Indonesia WHO Office on a program to expand that assistance and strengthen surveillance and diagnosis and emergency response for communicable diseases in Indonesia ($3 million over 3 years).
Papua New Guinea

While there are no known cases of avian influenza in PNG, the NAQIA does have a surveillance program carrying out quarterly testing in PNG’s border region with Indonesia. In addition, any poultry or blood samples that are sent for laboratory testing are routinely screened for HPAI.
East Timor

The Ministry of Health, with assistance from the WHO, has capacity to monitor and provide capacity development in surveillance of communicable diseases including HPAI virus in humans. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Division of Quarantine) is implementing a government directive to ban the import of poultry and poultry products. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries surveillance systems to detect an outbreak of the HPAI virus in poultry is based at all points of entry to the country e.g Dili airport and border entry points at Suai, Batucade (Bobonaro) and Oecussi.

(a), (b) and (c) (i) and (ii) Following outbreaks of Avian influenza in the region during 2004, Australia responded through the aid program with a $650,000 contribution in support of regional WHO responses through the WHO’s Western Pacific Regional Office and the South East Asian Regional Office (these offices’ mandates include coverage of Indonesia, PNG and East Timor). A further $350,000 was provided to DAFF for short term technical assistance aimed at enabling it and the CSIRO Animal Health Laboratory in Geelong to respond to the epidemiological and diagnostic needs arising from the outbreak.

AusAID has since designed a program (Emerging and Resurging Zoonotic Diseases Regional Initiative Program) of assistance to strengthen the capacity of East Asian countries to identify and respond to outbreaks of Avian Influenza and other related diseases, through a number of scientific collaborative activities between the differing disciplines of human and animal health, as well as between Australian and ASEAN (and its member countries) agencies.

This three year, $5 million AusAID funded program will start in July 2005 and will address gaps in the areas of surveillance and reporting, human and animal health laboratory diagnostic capacity, and emergency preparedness.
The program will be delivered by DAFF; WHO; the ASEAN Secretariat; and supported by a targeted research program by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.

In advance of the above activity, in July 2004, $650,000 was also provided through the ASEAN Australia Development Cooperation Program to help build the region’s capacity to deal with infectious disease outbreaks.

The DAFF is involved in capacity building in animal health in Indonesia, PNG and East Timor. The projects are implemented in response to gaps identified by the DAFF in consultation with host Governments.
More detailed information by country is outlined below:
Indonesia

In March 2004, the Australian Government, through the bilateral aid program contributed $325,000 for initial assistance focussing on epidemiological investigation, public information and awareness raising and supply of anti-viral medications. In June 2004, AusAID signed an MOU with the Indonesia WHO Office on a program to expand that assistance to focus on strengthening the sensitivity and timeliness of surveillance, the capacity within the health system to react to surveillance data and the links between ministry of health and agriculture response structures. It will be an ongoing program with the flexibility to address any emerging issues or limitations ($3 million over 3 years).
Recent discussions between Ministries of Health resulted in an agreement to escalate collaboration on communicable disease between Australia and Indonesia.
Papua New Guinea

The NAQIA is working with the Australian Chief Veterinary Officer to develop a proposal for Australian assistance to improve its surveillance and diagnostic capacity. NAQIA is also about to commence a regional FAO program on surveillance and diagnostics.
East Timor

The Ministry of Health advises that it has the ability to provide an initial response in the event of a small outbreak of the HPAI virus in humans, but would not have the capacity or resources to contain a major outbreak. WHO assesses that assistance in the area of surveillance is a key priority for East Timor at this stage.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries advises that the current cooperation with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) needs to be sustained because the Government of Timor Leste places great reliance on the AQIS facilities and resources based in Darwin.

(7) (a), (b) and (c) (i) and (ii) Various capacity building projects in Indonesia, PNG and East Timor have included training in disease recognition, survey design and implementation and emergency response.
Indonesia
See information under (6) above
Papua New Guinea

AusAID has not provided direct aid assistance yet to prepare for the HPAI virus. Aid support so far has been provided through the establishment of the Central Public Health Laboratory which will go through accreditation in 2 years time as a WHO reference lab; production of public health manuals and discussions on epidemic responsiveness; and installation of health radios to help provide a health communication network throughout the country.
East Timor

There are no known cases of avian influenza in East Timor and AusAID has not received any requests for assistance in relation to Avian Influenza from the Government of East Timor. However, there has been ongoing cooperation between the Government of East Timor and Australian Government agencies as outlined in information under (4) and (6) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 March 2005:

item.para: Is he aware that Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited condition in which a defective enzyme in the liver prevents the normal breakdown of the amino acid, phenylalanine, which is present in most foods; if not, why.
Is he aware that there are

item.label: (a)
item.para: approximately 25 babies born in Australia each year with PKU,

item.label: (b)
item.para: over 200 patients in NSW attending the PKU Service based at the Children’s Hospital at Westmead, and

item.label: (c)
item.para: approximately 500 individuals with PKU nationally; if not, why.

Can he confirm that the only effective treatment for PKU is a strictly controlled diet which provides enough protein to ensure normal growth and development but not enough to cause an excess which may result in brain damage and that it is difficult, costly and inconvenient; if not, why not.
Can he confirm that

item.label: (a)
item.para: high doses of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) in PKU patients may help to reduce the blood phenylalanine concentration,

item.label: (b)
item.para: BH4 is available as a tablet,

item.label: (c)
item.para: some PKU patients taking BH4 tablets may be able to have a more ‘relaxed’ diet or even come off the PKU diet altogether, and

item.label: (d)
item.para: the BH4 tablet is expensive and not currently available through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS); if not, why not.
Are individuals who are on a PKU diet eligible for

item.label: (a)
item.para: the Health Carer’s Allowance and

item.label: (b)
item.para: the low protein diet allowance; if so, what is the cost to the Commonwealth; if not, why not.
Are the specialised medical formulas which are essential to a PKU diet subsidised and available on the PBS; if not, why not.
Has the Government considered whether there would be savings if the provision of BH4 on the PBS allowed a PKU sufferer to manage without the

item.label: (a)
item.para: Health Carer’s Allowance,

item.label: (b)
item.para: low-protein allowance, and

item.label: (c)
item.para: specialised medical formula; if so, what are they.
Will he take steps to have BH4 included on the PBS for the treatment of PKU; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In 2001 when the then Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Dr Michael Wooldridge, initiated assistance for people with an Inborn Error of Metabolism (IEM), of which Phenylketonuria (PKU) is the most common condition, there was extensive liaison with specialists in the field, in particular the members of the Australasian Society for Inborn Errors of Metabolism. The advice of these experts was taken on the technical aspects of the disease. This led to the grant arrangements currently in place to assist people with this condition.

(2) (a) (b) and (c) There are estimated to be 900 people in Australia with an IEM, the most common of which is PKU. The majority of the new applications received for the Australian Government grant of $204 per month to assist in meeting the costs of maintaining a special diet are for babies. However, there are also applications from adolescents and adults returning to the diet as well as pregnant women.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: (b) and (c) There are estimated to be 900 people in Australia with an IEM, the most common of which is PKU. The majority of the new applications received for the Australian Government grant of $204 per month to assist in meeting the costs of maintaining a special diet are for babies. However, there are also applications from adolescents and adults returning to the diet as well as pregnant women.

As far back as 2001, Dr Wooldridge acknowledged the difficulties faced by people with PKU, and the high cost diet that is required to enable people with an IEM to afford to stay on strict diets and consequently ensure their long term health is maintained. The Australian Government initiated a grant program to subsidise the cost of special food, and continues to provide support to people with PKU in the form of this grant program.

(4) (a) The manufacturer of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), Schircks Laboratories, has not sought marketing approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) for the drug in Australia. Hence, no research has been undertaken here to determine the efficacy of the drug.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The manufacturer of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), Schircks Laboratories, has not sought marketing approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) for the drug in Australia. Hence, no research has been undertaken here to determine the efficacy of the drug.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Schircks Laboratories has advised that BH4 is produced in tablet form.

item.label: (c)
item.para: As no registration for this product has been sought in Australia there is no available evidence for the Australian Government to assess whether taking BH4 tablets would enable PKU patients to relax their diet.

item.label: (d)
item.para: Medicines are made available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) on the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) - the independent expert group which advises the Australian Government on such matters. The members include doctors, health scientists, other health professionals and a consumer representative. The PBAC cannot consider subsidising a product for conditions which are outside those approved for the marketing of a drug in Australia. Marketing approval specifies those conditions where the product has been demonstrated to be safe and effective and is assessed by the TGA. The TGA has not granted marketing approval for BH4 for the condition PKU. See 4(a) above.

In addition, the PBAC has not received an application for listing of the drug on the PBS. Consequently, the PBAC is not in a position to recommend the listing of BH4 for subsidy under the PBS. Neither the Government nor the PBAC is able to compel the manufacturer to apply for registration and/or PBS listing of a particular product for the treatment of PKU. Decisions on these matters involve commercial and other considerations that can only be made by the manufacturer involved.
People with an IEM, including those with PKU, are entitled to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: A Carer allowance paid by the Department of Family and Community Services. This allowance is a supplementary payment available to people who provide daily care and attention at home for adults or children with a disability or chronic medical condition. The Carer allowance is not income or assets tested and is not treated as income for taxation purposes. It can be paid in addition to a social security income support payment.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The IEM grant of $204 per month is paid by the Department of Health and Ageing to each eligible person. This grant program cost approximately $1.7 million in 2003-04.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of making sure that patients with PKU have the best possible access to up-to-date and affordable medical and pharmaceutical treatments. There are a number of different medicines and products listed on the PBS specifically for use in PKU. In 2003-04 the Australian Government spent $7 million to subsidise these medicines.

No cost benefit analysis has been undertaken on (a) Health Carer’s Allowance, (b) low-protein allowance and (c) specialized medical formula versus use of BH4. The PBAC would carry out such an assessment if it received an application to list this product on the PBS. However, as this drug is not registered for use in Australia and no application for its registration has been received from the manufacturer this could not occur at this time.

Given the complex nature of the data required, the manufacturer of a product proposed for PBS listing is usually in the best position to submit an application in support of its request to the PBAC. In general, the submission must provide details of the drug and its proposed use on the PBS, data from comparative randomised trials, a modeled economic evaluation, and the estimated extent of use and financial implications.
I am unable to list a drug on the PBS without receiving a recommendation from the PBAC.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Is the Minister aware that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has budgeted only $2 million per year over the next five years for its free-to-air digital television channel (ABC2).
Is the Minister aware that the limited funding allocated for ABC2 will mean that there will be very few new programs and mainly repeat programs on ABC2.

Will the Government immediately grant additional funding to the ABC to ensure that ABC2 can broadcast a wider variety of programs, with a view to providing the national audience with a greater diversity of news, information, education, cultural and entertainment programs; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes. The ABC has indicated it is confident that the funding model for ABC2 is sustainable.

ABC2 screens a combination of both new and repeat programming, which is specifically designed to complement that provided by the primary ABC channel. The utilisation of repeat programming in ABC2’s schedule provides a valuable opportunity to make the most of the vast amounts of quality programming currently held in the ABC’s archive. It also greatly improves viewer access to the new content created by the ABC weekly, by making programming available at a range of times to suit viewer schedules. However, ABC2’s schedule is not limited to repeat programming, and also contains documentaries, children’s programming and performance pieces never before seen on Australian television, as well as a broad range of animation, video, and regional and educational programs created exclusively for ABC2 and ABC Broadband.
ABC funding is determined on a triennial basis, and is a Budget consideration for the Government. Management of that funding is a matter for the ABC Board.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: How many people and what proportion of households have access to digital television services.
How many people do not have access to digital television services.
What are the reasons preventing universal access to digital television services.
What proportion of programming on digital television is new content that has been developed by digital services broadcasters.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: According to industry estimates approximately 84 per cent of people have access to transmission of all the commercial and national television broadcasting services in their area, and around 96 per cent have access to digital transmission from at least one free to air broadcaster. Based on Australian Bureau of Statistics’ population estimates for Australia of around 20.2 million, this means that around 19 million people probably have access to at least one digital free to air television service, if they choose to purchase digital television receivers.
See answer to part (1).

Coverage of analog services is not universal. Some people are not able to receive analog transmissions due, for example, to interference or topography. The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 requires broadcasters to achieve equivalent coverage with their digital television services as is currently achieved by analog services, by the end of the eight year simulcast period.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 requires that the digital programming be a simulcast of the existing analog programming, with some exceptions. Therefore, the majority of programming on digital television is likely to be the same as that on analog television. However, some new digital services have been provided within the parameters of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, such as the ability of the national broadcasters to multichannel. SBS has used its spectrum to provide a digital World News Channel and the ABC recently launched its ABC2 digital channel which broadcasts some unique content. The legislation also requires broadcasters to provide a minimum of 1040 hours per year of high definition digital television programming. It is not possible to quantify the percentage of new digital content as a proportion of the overall service.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Is he aware of recent media reports on the views of some Government backbench members that lower and middle income earners pay far too much income tax.
Will the Government respond to those members of the Coalition who are calling for the income tax-free threshold to be raised to $10,000 per annum; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
Will the Government respond to those members of the Coalition who are calling for the top marginal rate of income tax to start at $100,000 per annum; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (3) I refer the honourable member to the 2005-06 Budget which included measures to cut taxes for all Australians.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Is Australia a signatory to the (a) Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons (1954) and (b) Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness (1954).

Has the Government fulfilled its international obligations as a signatory to the (a) Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons (1954) and (b) Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness (1954); if so, will the Minister explain how; if not, why not.
Can a person who is not found to be a refugee but is found to be a stateless person seek protection in Australia as a stateless person under Australian law; if not, why not.

What steps is the Minister taking to fulfil Australia’s obligations under international instruments to which Australia is a signatory, to reduce the incidence of statelessness; if no steps are being taken, can the Minister explain why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Yes, Australia is a party to both (a) the Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons (1954) and (b) the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness (1961).
Yes, Australia fulfils its obligations under these Conventions through a range of laws and policies.

(a) Key obligations in the Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons include non-discrimination, freedom of religion, treatment not less favourable than other non-citizens who are not stateless in relation to access to certain services, provision of travel documents and non-expulsion of stateless lawful non-citizens except in certain circumstances. These obligations are implemented through migration legislation and policy and a range of Commonwealth and State and Territory laws (for example in relation to non-discrimination and provision of welfare).

(b) Key obligations in the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness relate to the acquisition and loss of nationality and have been fulfilled through the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 since before the Convention came into force in 1975.

The Statelessness Conventions do not confer a right for stateless persons to enter or remain in Australia. The 1954 Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons is primarily concerned with ensuring that stateless persons are not treated less favourably than persons who have a nationality. In the context of the Refugees Convention, Australia meets this obligation by ensuring that stateless persons are not disadvantaged in applying for protection because they do not have a nationality.

Where it is determined that Australia does not owe a stateless person protection obligations under the Refugees Convention, unique or exceptional circumstances may exist which warrant the exercise of the Minister’s discretionary, non-compellable public interest powers under s417 of the Migration Act 1958. Obligations under other relevant treaties such as the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights may be assessed in the context of these powers.

The most comprehensive international instrument in relation to the reduction of statelessness to which Australia is a party is the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. As explained in response to question (2)(b), Australia fulfils these obligations through the Australian Citizenship Act 1948.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Has there been an increase in the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases in Australia over the last 10 years; if so, what types of STD’s are increasing.
Can he say whether the Commonwealth’s expenditure on family planning associations and the Government’s Family Planning Program has been an effective campaign against STD’s in Australia.
What other steps is he taking in a bid to reduce the incidence of STD’s in Australia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: According to the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS), the number of notifications of chlamydia and gonorrhoea has increased over the last 10 years.

The objective of the National Family Planning Program is to provide a balanced approach to differing family planning service models, aimed at promoting responsible sexual and reproductive behaviours, rather than focusing on Sexually Transmissible Infections (STIs) per se in Australia.

One of the key components of the funding to the Family Planning Organisations under the National Family Planning Program is for the provision of sex education predominantly to groups who would not usually access mainstream health services. However, due to the large range of factors that impact on STIs, it is not possible using available evidence to determine whether any changes in the number of STIs reported in Australia is related solely to the National Family Planning Program.

The Australian Government is currently finalising the new National Sexually Transmissible Infections (STIs) Strategy which will provide a platform for specific actions to address these infections. This Strategy is expected to be released in the first half of 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

quote.para: How many (a) trainees and (b) apprentices were in training in the electoral division of Throsby in each year since 1996.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Sport, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: What projects did the Australia Council fund in the Sydney metropolitan area during (a) 2003-2004 and (b) 2004-2005.
In respect to each project, what was (a) the expenditure on, (b) its location, and (c) its purpose.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Arts and Sport has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: and (2) The Australia Council has provided details of the projects it funded in 27 Federal electorates covering the Sydney metropolitan area during 2003-04 and from 1 July 2004 to 31 January 2005. Because of its volume, this information has been provided separately to the honourable member and a summary is below.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Has the review into the safety of the Ilyushin aircraft and its use by the Australian Defence Force (ADF) been completed; if so, what were the main findings of the review.
Can the review be made public; if not, why not.
Have any additional financial or non-financial resources been specifically allocated to ensure that the findings and recommendations of the review are implemented by the ADF.
What has the Government done to implement the findings or recommendations arising as a result of the review.
Have the findings and recommendations of this review been incorporated into the ADF planning and procedures manuals and handbooks and into any future contract documents.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: An independent safety case review has been completed. The safety case risk assessment and recommendations have been developed into options for future airworthiness management. Until the new regulatory framework has been developed and implemented, outcomes of the review are reflected in Airworthiness Directive 05/2004, which states in part:

‘Whenever any Australian Defence Organisation personnel are transported, 1 Joint Movement Group is limited to Western built aircraft whose operators are authorised for Regular Public Transport operations by the Federal Aviation Administration, Transport Canada, European Joint Aviation Authority (full member countries), New Zealand Civil Aviation Authority, Civil Aviation Safety Authority or are operated by Australia, Canada, United Kingdom, United States and New Zealand military forces.’

The results of the review are available to the public, in the form of Airworthiness Directive 05/2004, when requested from the Airworthiness Coordination and Policy Agency ‑ Air Force. The independent report is commercial-in-confidence and cannot be released publicly.
Yes.

In September 2002, the Minister for Defence directed the Australian Defence Force Airworthiness Authority to implement acceptable processes to satisfy the Australian Defence Force’s duty-of-care and airworthiness management responsibilities. The Government (through the Minister for Defence) continues to be fully informed on the progress.

While the Airworthiness Directive implements findings of the safety case in the interim, development of the mature airworthiness management system for civil charter operations by the ADF is ongoing. The Airworthiness Directive and the mature system both apply to all current and future charter activity, including contractual arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister provide an assessment of the progress of Project Land 134.
What is the total planned expenditure for the project.
What is the current planned year of delivery and does the planned year of delivery differ from that outlined in the latest Defence Capability Plan.

Can the Minister confirm that parties responding to the tender were asked to sign a Confidentiality Agreement about the tender and the process; if so, have any of the contractors not adhered to that agreement and were any sanctions applied.
Will the project provide the Army with the capability originally specified in the final contract.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The tender for Project Land 134 Phase 1 was completed in September 2002 and a contract signed with Oscmar International Limited (Auckland, New Zealand) in January 2003. Oscmar was not able to meet key milestones during 2003 and a re-negotiated schedule representing 12-months delay was agreed in May 2004. This incorporated a package of additional consideration measures in favour of the Commonwealth of Australia. Subsequently, Oscmar has met key milestones in 2004 and the first quarter of 2005.
Total planned expenditure for Land 134 Phase 1 is $62,400,764 (January 2005 prices).
2006 as specified in the Defence Capability Plan 2000 (2000-2010). As an approved project, Land 134 is not included in the Defence Capability Plan 2004-2014.
The parties responding to the Land 134 tender were not required to sign a confidentiality agreement about the tender and the process.
Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: What sum was provided to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the postcode areas (i) 3004, (ii) 3006, (iii) 3145, (iv) 3161, (v) 3162, (vi) 3163, (vii) 3182, (viii) 3183, (ix) 3184, (x) 3185, (xi) 3205, (xii) 3206, and (xiii) 3207 for 2004.
What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of each grant in 2004.

What sum will be provided to (a) government, and (b) non-government schools in the postcode area (i) 3004, (ii) 3006, (iii) 3145, (iv) 3161, (v) 3162, (vi) 3163, (vii) 3182, (viii) 3183, (ix) 3184, (x) 3185, (xi) 3205, (xii) 3206, and (xiii) 3207 for 2005.
What will (a) the expenditure be for, (b) be the location of, and (c) be the purpose of each grant in 2005.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for government schools is not reported at the level of detail requested. Australian Government General Recurrent Grants for government schools are provided to the government education authority in each State or Territory, on the basis of total enrolments. The State or Territory determines where the grants are used. Payments to individual schools are not recorded.

The Department of Education, Science and Training is therefore unable to provide postcode detail for General Recurrent Grants to government schools. In 2004, Capital funding amounting to $500,000 was provided to government schools in identified postcodes. No Flagpole or BELS funding was provided to government schools in the identified postcodes in 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Total Australian Government funding for non-government schools cannot be reported at the level of detail requested. Funding from Australian Government programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the identified post codes totalled $44,883,150. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding provided $271,000, Flagpole funding provided $1,260, General Recurrent Grants funding provided $44,601,890 and Establishment Grant funding provided $9,000 to non‑government schools in the identified postcodes for 2004. No BELS funding was provided to non‑government schools in the identified postcodes in 2004.

(2) (a) and (b)Details on the expenditure and location for the identified postcodes for 2004 are as follows: Capital funding to government schools is at Table 1, Attachment A; Capital funding to non-government schools is at Table 2, Attachment A; Flagpole funding to non‑government schools is at Table 3, Attachment A; General Recurrent funding to non-government schools is at Table 4 at Attachment A, and Establishment Grant funding is at Table 5, at Attachment A.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The purpose of the Australian Government Capital Grants is to assist in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.
The purpose of Flagpole funding is to assist schools with their civics and citizenship education activities, and promoting values education in Australian schools.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

The purpose of Australian Government Establishment Grants is to assist newly commencing schools with the recurrent costs incurred in the formative years and enable them to be more competitive with existing schools.

(3) (a) Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested (see response to 1a). Information about 2005 Capital Grants for government schools is not yet available. To date, no Flagpole funding or BELS funding has been provided to government schools in the identified postcodes for 2005.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Estimates of total Australian Government funding for 2005 for non-government schools are not maintained at the level of detail requested. Estimated funding from Australian Government Programmes that can be reported at this level of detail for non-government schools in the identified postcodes amounts to $42,710,475 for 2005. Of this amount, Capital Grants funding will provide an estimated $150,000 and General Recurrent Grants funding will provide an estimated $42,560,475 for non‑government schools in the identified postcodes for 2005. To date, no Flagpole funding or BELS funding has been provided to non-government schools in the electoral division of Capricornia and identified postcodes for 2005.

(4) (a) and (b)Details on the estimated expenditure and location for the identified postcodes for 2005 are as follows: Estimated Capital grants to non-government schools is at Table 6 at Attachment A; Estimated General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools is at Table 7 at Attachment A.

The purpose of Australian Government General Recurrent Grants is to help schools with the recurrent cost of school education so that they can offer students education directed towards the achievement of the Australian Government’s priorities for schooling.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: What has been the cost to the taxpayer of the flyover by RAAF aircraft at the Formula One Grand Prix at Albert Park, Melbourne, for each year since the flyover commenced.
How many (a) aircraft, (b) aircrew, and (c) groundcrew have been involved in providing this service for each year since it was first provided.
What is the Government’s justification for this expenditure from the Defence budget to provide entertainment for a commercial sporting event.

Has the Government made any effort to recoup the cost of providing this service from the commercial organisers of the Formula One Grand Prix; if so, (a) what form did these efforts take and (b) what was the result; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: No additional cost has been incurred as flying displays are conducted within flying hours planned and budgeted for as part of the annual flying hour program. Also refer to answers given to Questions No 23 and 343 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, pages 3144 and 3207); and 1539 (Hansard, 13 May 2003, page 14316).

item.label: (a)
item.para: Seven.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Seven.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Six.

Defence participation was approved on the basis of significant public relations and recruiting benefits. Refer to the answers given to Questions No 1539 (Hansard, 13 May 2003, page 14316) and 1567 (Hansard, 21 June 2000, page 18023).
Refer to the answer given to Question No 1539 (Hansard, 13 May 2003, page 14316).

Teachers at the College aimed to improve students’ engagement in learning and build a culture of high expectations, raising literacy and numeracy levels and addressing absenteeism and retention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: How many Job Network providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Shortland and what are their names and addresses.
How many job seekers are currently registered with (a) each Job Network provider and (b) each office of each provider in the electorate of Shortland.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the electoral division of Shortland, how many Newstart or Youth Allowance recipients were placed into jobs through assistance from Job Network providers.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many long-term unemployed people (i) in total and (ii) as a proportion of all unemployed people, participated in intensive assistance programs in the electoral division of Shortland.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many of the people who have participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Shortland have participated on (i) one occasion, (ii) two occasions, (iii) three occasions, and (iv) more than three occasions.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many job seekers who participated in intensive assistance in the electoral division of Shortland found employment and what proportion found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment.
How many Work for the Dole providers are currently operating in the electoral division of Shortland, what are their names and addresses and what programs do they offer.
For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Shortland found employment.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, what proportion of people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Shortland found (i) full-time, (ii) part-time, and (iii) casual employment following their placement.

For the year (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004, how many people who participated in a Work for the Dole program in the electoral division of Shortland were in (i) full-time, (ii) parttime, (iii) casual employment three months after completing their placement.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr Andrews

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) Job Network is administered on the basis of 19 Labour Market Regions and 137 Employment Services Areas (ESAs), the boundaries of which do not align with those of Federal Electorates. Job seekers choose Job Network members for a variety of reasons including location, proximity to transport routes and Centrelink offices, or the satisfaction of friends and others. Job seekers residing in one Electorate or ESA may be assisted through Job Network sites located in adjoining Electorates or ESAs. For illustration, job seekers residing in the Electorate of Shortland may be assisted through Job Network sites located in the Electorates of Newcastle, Charlton or Dobell. The Central Coast Sydney ESA and Lower Hunter ESA are most closely aligned with the Electorate of Shortland and, therefore, answers are provided with reference to these two ESAs.

There are currently 16 Job Network members and other Job Placement Organisations operating in the Central Coast Sydney ESA and 29 in the Lower Hunter ESA. Their names, office locations and the number of job seekers on their caseloads are shown in Table 1.
Table 1 Job Network Sites – Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter Employment Services Areas

para.inline: ORS Rehabilitation & Placement Services Pty Ltd
Shop 13, The Gateway Centre, 237 Mann Street
Shop 1001, Lake Haven Business Park, Lake Haven Drive
Golf Links Est, Unit 3 Amy Close, 300 Pacific Highway
A1 Employment and Training Services Pty Ltd
MBA Newcastle Group Training Pty Limited
Hunter Mall Chambers, Level 2, 175 Scott Street

item.para: *JNM = Job Network member.
*JPO = Job Placement Organisation.

Notes: Site details and job seeker numbers are as at 11 March 2005. Caseload numbers are for the “JN Active Caseload”, that is job seekers currently in assistance with a JN site or very recently referred for assistance. Caseload numbers are at a point in time and change as job seekers are referred to a site or exit assistance at the site. JPOs are not allocated a specific business share, but compete to secure vacancies from employers and to refer eligible job seekers.

The numbers of Newstart and Youth Allowance (Other) recipients placed into jobs by Job Network providers and other Job Placement Organisations in the years 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003 and 2004, in (i) Australia and (ii) the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs, are shown in Table 2.
Table 2 Total Job Placements for Newstart and Youth Allowance Recipients

Note: Numbers for 2003 and 2004 include placements made by Job Placement Only Organisations that do not deliver Job Network services. Total Job Placements include those that may become long term job outcomes at a later stage.

Details of the number of long term unemployed jobseekers commencing in Intensive Assistance in the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs in the years 2000, 2001, 2002 and 2003 are shown in Table 3.

The delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003. The delivery of the new Intensive Support service under the Active Participation Model (APM) commenced on 1 July 2003. Details of long term unemployed Intensive Support participant numbers in the Central Coast Sydney and the Lower Hunter ESAs in the years 2003 and 2004 are shown in Table 4.
Table 3 Intensive Assistance Commencements for the Long Term Unemployed

item.para: Notes: Long term unemployed job seekers are those registered as unemployed for 12 months or more. Numbers for Intensive Assistance in 2003 are to 13 June 2003 when job seekers ceased commencing Intensive Assistance prior to the introduction of the APM on 1 July 2003.
Table 4 Intensive Support Long Term Unemployed Participants

entry.para: of Total Participants in Intensive Support
of Total Participants in Intensive Support

item.para: Notes: Long term unemployed job seekers are those registered as unemployed for 12 months or more. Numbers for Intensive Support in 2003 are from 1 July 2003 when the APM commenced. Job seekers eligible for Job Search Support Only have been excluded from the calculation of percentages. The number of participants refers to all job seekers assisted in Intensive Support in that year.
In view of the 12 month duration of Intensive Assistance it is not practical to report on the numbers of job seekers who participated on multiple occasions in 2000, 2001, 2002 and 2003.

Delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003. From 1 July 2003, improvements to the delivery of Job Network services were introduced through implementation of the APM. While Intensive Assistance allowed for multiple episodes of assistance, the new APM arrangements provide for job seekers to be assisted by a single Job Network member for the full duration of their unemployment, allowing the service provider to develop a detailed understanding of each job seeker’s needs.

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients.

Outcomes estimates for Intensive Assistance for the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs are shown in Table 5. Table 5 includes (a) the total proportion in employment and (b) the proportions in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment following their placements.
Table 5 Intensive Assistance Post Programme Monitoring Outcomes
Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs

Notes: Outcomes relate to the status of clients 3 months after exiting Intensive Assistance as reported by respondents to the PPM survey. Casual employment includes employment on a temporary, seasonal or casual basis, which may be full time or part time.

The delivery of Intensive Assistance ceased on 30 June 2003, and as a result PPM survey data for Intensive Assistance for 2003 and 2004 are not available. The delivery of the new Intensive Support service under the APM commenced on 1 July 2003. PPM survey data for Intensive Support at the ESA level are not yet available.

Community Work Coordinators (CWCs) are contracted to provide Work for the Dole services on an ESA basis. The CWCs providing services in the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs and their office locations are shown in Table 6.
Table 6 Community Work Co-ordinators and Site Locations

and (10) Work for the Dole is a work experience programme. Employment is not a stated objective of the programme, however, the valuable work experience gained through the programme combined with the continued support of the Job Network, supports the objectives of the APM.

The Post-Programme Monitoring (PPM) survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations measures job seekers’ outcomes three months after they have left assistance. PPM survey results are an estimate of outcomes levels based on responses from a sample of clients.

Outcomes estimates for Work for the Dole for the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs are shown in Table 7. Table 7 includes (a) the total proportion in employment and (b) the proportions in (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual employment following their placements.
Table 7 Work for the Dole Post Programme Monitoring Outcomes
Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs

Notes: Outcomes relate to the status of clients 3 months after exiting Intensive Assistance as reported by respondents to the PPM survey. Casual employment includes employment on a temporary, seasonal or casual basis, which may be full time or part time. There were insufficient numbers of survey respondents in the Central Coast Sydney and Lower Hunter ESAs to provide statistically reliable outcome estimates for Work for the Dole for 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, in writing, on 17 March 2005:

item.para: How many (a) community-based and (b) private child care centres are located in the electoral division of Shortland and what is the name and address of each centre.
In respect of each centre, what sum did the Commonwealth provide for the financial year (a) 2000-01, (b) 2001-02, (c) 2002-03, and (d) 2003-04 and from which programs was the funding provided.
How many children in the electoral division of Shortland are catered for in (a) community-based and (b) private child care centres.
How many Children in the electoral division of Shortland are (a) under two years of age and (b) under two years of age and enrolled in (i) community-based and (ii) private child care centres.
How many Commonwealth funded places for (a) Before School, (b) After School Care, and (c) Vacation care are there in the electoral division of Shortland.
Which organisations in the electoral division of Shortland coordinate the provision of these services.
